<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 214, 902, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 300, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 387, 406]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 903, 90]]<|/det|>
During this time, the thrust exerted on the space probe by the motor remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
On a particular day, the atmospheric pressure is \(1.0 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\). A bubble of gas forms at a point \(5.0 \text{m}\) below the surface of a lake. The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 148, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 247, 135]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 151, 602, 167]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[492, 257, 918, 274]]<|/det|>
<form>pressure = ...........................................................................[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 288, 180, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[492, 383, 918, 400]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 846, 477]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A beaker contains some water at room temperature. A student places a mercury-in-glass thermometer in the water with the bulb of the thermometer just beneath the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 387, 136]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows the arrangement.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[307, 148, 683, 348]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 397, 917, 429]]<|/det|>
<pre>The student uses an electric fan to blow air across the open top of the beaker. She notices that the reading on the thermometer begins to decrease.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 444, 146, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 917, 476]]<|/det|>

<pre>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 644, 148, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 644, 917, 692]]<|/det|>
The student places the thermometer near the bottom of the beaker. The electric fan continues to blow air across the top of the beaker. After some time, the student observes that the temperature of the water at the bottom of the beaker is decreasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 707, 917, 738]]<|/det|>
